raijin.commandlineargs

This module contains a simple class that processes command line arguments and stores them in a hashtable. The hash table is static so this class object can be created multiple times without having to reinitialize it when the arguments from main.

Author:
Paul Crane

class CommandLineArgs;
Handles the processing of command line arguments.

Examples:
auto arguments = ["testapp", "-flag", "-value=this is a test", "-aFloat=4.44"];
auto args = new CommandLineArgs;

args.addFlag("flag", "A test flag");
args.addCommand("aFloat", 3.14, "A float value");
args.addCommand("integer", 100, "Sets value");
args.addCommand("value", "hello world", "Just a silly value.");
args.process(arguments);

assert(args.asBoolean("flag") == true);
assert(args["flag"] == true);

import std.math;

float aFloat = args.asDecimal("aFloat");

assert(feqrel(args.asDecimal("aFloat"), 4.44));
assert(feqrel(aFloat, 4.44));

assert(feqrel(args.asInteger("aFloat"), 4.44));

assert(args.contains("integer") == true);
assert(args.contains("valuez") == false);
assert(args["integer"] == 100);


final @trusted void addFlag(const string key, const string description, RequiredArg required = RequiredArg.no);
Registers a flag argument eg. --flag

Params:
string key Name of the command line argument to register.
string description The description of what the command line argument does.
RequiredArg required Whether the argument is required.

final @trusted DynamicType opIndex(const string key);
Retrieves the value of key where key is the name of the command line argument. T is the the type that returned value should be converted to.

Params:
string key Name of the command line argument to get.

Returns:
The value of value of the command line argument to get. If the key isn't found it will return an raijin.typeutils.DynamicType.

final @trusted void opIndexAssign(T)(T value, const string key);
Assigns a value to a commandline argument stored internally.

final @trusted void opIndexAssign(ArgValues values, const string key);
Assigns a value to a commandline argument stored internally but uses ArgValues as the value.

final @safe bool contains(const string key);
Determines if the key(command line argument) exists.

Params:
string key Name of the key to get the value from.

Returns:
true if the command line argument exists, false otherwise.

final @safe T safeGet(T = string)(const size_t index, string defaultValue = string.init);
Retrieves the raw value passed via the command line in a safe way.

Params:
size_t index The integer value denoting the number of the argument passed.
string defaultValue Default value to use if the index is out of range.

Returns:
The value of the command line argument at index or defaultValue otherwise.

nothrow @safe string getProgramName();
Returns the name of the program.

Returns:
The name of the program.

nothrow @safe void setProgramVersion(const string programVersion);
Sets the programs version string to be used with -version argument.

Params:
string programVersion Text used when -version argument is called.

@trusted void onPrintHelp();
Default print method for printing registered command line options.

@trusted void onPrintVersion();
Prints the program version string when -version argument is passed.

@trusted void onInvalidArg(const string error, const string command);
Called when an invalid argument is passed on the command line.

@trusted void onValidArgs();
Called when an valid argument is passed on the command line.

@trusted void onValidArg(const string argument);
Called each time a valid argument is passed.

@trusted void onNoArgs();
Called when an valid argument is passed on the command line.

bool process(string[] arguments, IgnoreNonArgs ignoreNonArgs = IgnoreNonArgs.no, AllowInvalidArgs allowInvalidArgs = AllowInvalidArgs.no);
Handles the registration of command line arguments passed to the program. This is the internal command line argument processing method. The method processArgs should be used as it simplifies handling of command line arguments.

Params:
string[] arguments The arguments that are sent from main()
IgnoreNonArgs ignoreNonArgs Ignore the first argument passed and continue processing the remaining arguments
AllowInvalidArgs allowInvalidArgs Any invalid arguments will be ignored and won't be called.

Note:
Setting allowInvalidArgs.yes will also cause onInvalidArgs to not be fired. Resulting in invalid data in a command.
